headline.main: A Genomic Treasure Hunt May Be Striking Gold

docs.abstract: Article on genetic research by Dr Kari Stefansson, direct descendant of Vikings who began kidnapping young Celtic women and carrying them off to Iceland in 874; Stefansson's six-year-old company, Decode Genetics, reportedly has mapped general location of errant genes for 20 of 50 common diseases, found region holding longevity gene and identified specific disease-causing genes in three, those for schizophrenia and two forms of stroke; photo; map; diagrams (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: In the year 874, Viking crews from western Norway started to drop in on Ireland, capture an allotment of young Celtic women and sail off northwest to a remote island beyond the reach of retribution. Eleven centuries later, a direct descendant of those Icelandic pirates and their slave wives, Dr. Kari Stefansson, says he is starting to extract a tremendous prize, made possible by Iceland's tiny, isolated population and its obsessive interest in genealogy: a catalog of the deviant genes that cause the most common human diseases.

docs.abstract: Andrew Beck letter on Jane Brody's June 11 Personal Health column holds Ameicans eat unhealthily because complex dietary theories confuse them; drawing
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: High-calorie diets increase vulnerability to obesity and diabetes. Though doctors acknowledge the truth of this simple statement, the nation becomes fatter and more diabetic.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    High-calorie diets increase vulnerability to obesity and diabetes. Though doctors acknowledge the truth of this simple statement, the nation becomes fatter and more diabetic.

docs.abstract: Survey by University of Michigan Health System and Ann Arbor Veterans Administration Medical Center finds over one-third of nation's top-rated hospitals have fast food facilities on premises even though fast food is prime factor in burgeoning American obesity problem (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: It's an age-old question, popping up in many fields: Do you give people what they want or what's good for them (at the risk they will take their business elsewhere)? Newspapers, for instance, must weigh vital foreign news against a diet heavy on sports and celebrity gossip.
